column2: The visuals in this movie are absolutely breathtaking. Every frame is a painting.
My jaw was on the floor when I realized K wasn't the chosen one, Deckard's daughter was.
The vibe is just immaculate. Neon noir at its absolute finest.
The twist that Deckard and Rachael had a child just breaks the entire world of Blade Runner. Insane.
Ryan Gosling was perfect as K. That quiet loneliness really sold the character.
Joi being just a product, a ghost in the machine, and then her 'death'... that hurt.
The sound design in this is incredible. The score slaps so hard.
Luv killing Madam Joshi was so cold. She was the best of the 'good guys'.
I love Joi, but is she 'real'? The movie asks so many good questions.
The final fight between K and Luv in the water was brutal and beautiful.
The giant hologram Joi scene is one of the most visually stunning things I've ever seen.
The moment K realizes the memory of the wooden horse isn't his, but Dr. Stelline's... heartbreaking.
This movie is a 3-hour mood. You just have to sink into it.
K dying in the snow at the end, finally feeling like a real human with a soul, was a perfect ending for him.
The pacing is slow, but it's deliberate. It makes you feel the emptiness of the world.
Deckard seeing his daughter for the first time through the glass... got me right in the feels.
Jared Leto as Wallace was so creepy and menacing.
The baseline test is so intense. 'Within cells interlinked'.
The opening scene with Dave Bautista was a perfect reintroduction to this world.
So the whole resistance is built around protecting the first replicant child. That's a huge deal.
I love the details of the world, like the protein farms and the giant sea wall.
The fact that Joi was just a mass-marketed illusion to make replicants feel special is so dark.
The atmosphere in this movie is everything.
Luv's single tear as she kills K shows that even she had some kind of emotion, which makes her scarier.
Is Deckard a replicant? They still left it ambiguous and I love it.
Ana Stelline being the miracle child, creating memories from inside a glass bubble, is such a poetic idea.
The cinematography deserves all the awards. Roger Deakins is a legend.
K's whole journey was to help someone else find their family, only to die alone. Tragic hero vibes.
The world of 2049 feels so much more broken and bleak than the original.
The final shot of Deckard meeting his daughter is the single ray of hope in the whole film.
The score by Hans Zimmer and Benjamin Wallfisch is a masterpiece.
Realizing that K's implanted memory was real, just not his, changes everything for his character.
I need a Joi of my own, not gonna lie.
The replicant resistance using the child as a symbol for their revolution is a powerful concept.
The sheer scale of the city is mind-boggling.
Wallace killing the newborn replicant was a shocking way to establish him as the main villain.
The ethical questions this movie raises about AI and what it means to be human are deep.
The reveal that the bones belonged to Rachael is the inciting incident for the whole plot.
That scene in the abandoned casino with Deckard and the Elvis hologram was surreal.
K's sacrifice to save Deckard and reunite him with his daughter proves he's 'more human than human'.
Luv is such a terrifying and effective villain.
The entire search for the child is a classic noir detective story in a sci-fi world.
The orange haze of Las Vegas was a stunning visual choice.
The moment K sees the giant Joi ad and realizes she calls everyone 'Joe' was a gut punch.
The idea of a replicant being born, not made, is the central mystery and it's brilliant.
Joi getting destroyed when Luv crushes the emanator was so sudden and brutal.
I love that the movie doesn't give you easy answers.
K finding the wooden horse and thinking he's the chosen one is such a great misdirect.
The fight scenes are so visceral and grounded.
The final scene is so quiet and powerful. K has fulfilled his purpose.
Ana Stelline is the true miracle, the key to the future of replicants.
K's journey from thinking he's special to realizing he's just another pawn is heartbreaking.
The whole aesthetic of the Wallace Corporation is so clean and sterile, it's creepy.
When Luv says 'I'm the best angel of all,' you know she's a stone-cold killer.
The memory maker scenes with Dr. Stelline were so fascinating.
The final image of K lying on the steps in the snow, at peace, is unforgettable.
The way the film explores loneliness and the need for connection is beautiful.
The reveal of Rachael's bones completely shatters the established order of the world.
I love the ambiguity of Joi's feelings. Were they real or just programming?
The moment Deckard is reunited with his daughter is what K fought and died for. So bittersweet.
The world feels so lived-in and real, despite being futuristic.
Wallace's calm, philosophical villainy is more terrifying than any screaming baddie.
The scene where K 'syncs' Joi with the pleasure model is so weird and sad.
The child is the ultimate weapon in the war between humans and replicants.
This is a movie that stays with you long after you've seen it.
The fact that the leader of the replicant resistance is a woman who works with Deckard is a great twist.
The entire movie is a search for a soul, and K finds one just as he loses his life.
The ending is tragic, but also strangely hopeful for the future of replicants.
The visual contrast between the rainy city and the desolate wasteland is stunning.
K realizing he was manufactured to hunt his own kind, and then choosing to save one, is the core of his arc.
I can't stop thinking about the 'interlinked' baseline test.
The death of the child's mother during childbirth is a key piece of the mystery.
The sound of the spinner flying through the city is iconic.
The fact that Luv is Wallace's 'best angel' makes her his most devoted and dangerous agent.
The moral complexity is off the charts. There are no easy good guys or bad guys.
The entire movie hinges on a secret that could start a war. Classic sci-fi noir.
The use of practical effects mixed with CGI is seamless.
The replicant uprising is coming, and Deckard's daughter is their symbol.
The quiet, emotional moments are what make this movie so special.
K's journey was to find out he wasn't the one, but that he could still choose to be a hero.
The atmosphere is so thick you could cut it with a knife.
The twist isn't just that a replicant had a child, but that K isn't that child.
Jared Leto's performance was so unsettling in the best way.
The final scene offers a glimmer of hope in a very dark world.
The movie is a slow burn, but the payoff is 100% worth it.
The way K protects Deckard and his secret at the end is the ultimate act of humanity.
The design of K's apartment and the Joi interface was so cool.
The revelation that Rachael, a replicant, could give birth naturally is the central miracle of the story.
The fight in the waves was one of the most cinematic brawls I've ever seen.
K's entire purpose shifted from hunting his own kind to saving their future.
The score perfectly captures the melancholy and wonder of the world.
He died to give Deckard the one thing he never had: a chance to meet his child.
The visual language of this film is just on another level.
The moment Luv finds Rachael's bones, you know nothing will be the same.
Denis Villeneuve is a master of creating mood and atmosphere.
The ending is the definition of bittersweet. He dies, but he dies for a cause, having found his humanity.
